What is MAIHDA? {background-color="#f0f0f0"}
Multilevel Analysis of Individual Heterogeneity and Discriminatory Accuracy
::: {.callout-note}
The "Gold Standard" for Quantitative Intersectional Analysis
Treats intersectional identities as random effects in multilevel models, revealing how multiple characteristics combine to create unique experiences beyond simple additive effects
:::
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Conventional Approach:

Examines factors separately
Assumes additive effects
Misses critical intersections
Generic policy recommendations
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
MAIHDA Approach:

Creates intersectional strata
Reveals multiplicative effects
Handles small cell sizes via shrinkage
Enables targeted interventions
:::

::::
::: {.callout-warning}
Three Extended MAIHDA Applications:

Spatial MAIHDA ‚Üí School Segregation Study
Longitudinal MAIHDA ‚Üí Teacher Retention Study
Policy Evaluation MAIHDA ‚Üí Transport & Accessibility Study
:::

Study 1: Educational Segregation {background-color="#7B3F99"}
Current Approach: Limitations {.smaller}
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Research Question
Which students experience educational segregation, and how does this vary across space and time?
::: {.callout-tip}
Current Aggregate Approach:

Calculates: Segregation indices by ethnicity and area
Shows: Overall levels of ethnic concentration in schools
Misses: Which specific students attend segregated schools
Cannot reveal: Intersectional vulnerabilities
:::

Current Method

Aggregate segregation indices
Treats ethnic groups as homogeneous
Cannot identify individual risk factors
Misses within-group heterogeneity
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
The Segregation Paradox
Aggregate data shows decreasing segregation, but which students still experience it?
::: {style="background-color: #f5f5f5; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Who Attends Segregated Schools?
Current methods can't answer:

Are Pakistani boys more affected than Pakistani girls?
Does social class intersect with ethnicity?
Where do vulnerable groups cluster?
:::

::: {.callout-warning}
Definition of Segregated School:
Schools where >70% of students are from a single ethnic group (following Burgess & Wilson, 2005)
:::
:::
::::
::: {.callout-important}
Limitation
Aggregate approaches hide intersectional experiences - we need individual-level analysis to understand WHO experiences segregation, not just HOW MUCH segregation exists
:::
Spatial MAIHDA Enhancement {.smaller}
Individual-Level Spatial MAIHDA Innovation
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Method Enhancement:

Unit: Individual students (N = 3.2 million)
Outcome: Attends segregated school (binary)
24 intersectional strata: Ethnicity √ó SES √ó Gender
Cross-classified with spatial units (LSOAs)
Monte Carlo: 10,000 simulations

logit(Y_ijk) = Œ≥‚ÇÄ + u‚ÇÄj[strata] + v‚ÇÄk[LSOA] + W*spatial_effects
Key Innovation: Reveals WHO is most likely to experience segregation, not just WHERE segregation exists
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
Probability of Attending Segregated School:

::: {style="background-color: #e6f3ff; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Discriminatory Accuracy: ICC = 0.15
85% of variation is within intersectional groups - context matters more than identity alone
:::

::::
# Create simplified spatial concentration visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Create data for visualization
spatial_data <- data.frame(
  city = c("Bradford", "Birmingham", "East London"),
  x = c(25, 45, 85),
  y = c(50, 40, 30),
  risk = c(72, 69, 74),
  radius = c(40, 45, 50)
)

ggplot(spatial_data) +
  geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y, size = radius), 
             color = "#FF6B6B", alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_text(aes(x = x, y = y, label = paste0(city, "\n", risk, "% risk")),
            size = 3.5, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(15, 25), guide = "none") +
  xlim(0, 100) + ylim(0, 80) +
  labs(title = "Spatial Concentration of Pakistani √ó Low SES Students in Segregated Schools",
       subtitle = "Size indicates affected population") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 14, hjust = 0.5),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, hjust = 0.5))
::: {.callout-important}
Critical Finding
Monte Carlo reveals Pakistani low-SES boys have 71.2% [95% CI: 68.4%-73.8%] probability of attending segregated schools, with strong spatial clustering (Moran's I = 0.82) in specific urban areas. This intersectional vulnerability was invisible in aggregate analyses.
:::
Study 2: Teacher Retention {background-color="#7B3F99"}
Current Approach: Tracking the 2011 Cohort {.smaller}
Traditional Survival Analysis
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Current Method Limitations:

Cox model with additive effects
Assumes: ethnicity + gender + ITT = risk
Misses intersectional experiences
Cannot identify time-specific vulnerabilities

::: {.callout-tip}
Hidden Variation:
Overall retention rates mask huge differences:

Female: 16.54% - but ranges from 8% to 24% by intersectional group
No ITT: 9.75% - but some groups retain at 18%, others at 3%
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
# Create simplified Kaplan-Meier visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Create survival curve data
years <- 0:11
retention_itt <- c(100, 92, 84, 76, 68, 60, 52, 45, 38, 32, 26, 16.85)
retention_no_itt <- c(100, 88, 75, 62, 50, 40, 32, 25, 20, 15, 12, 9.75)

survival_data <- data.frame(
  Year = rep(years, 2),
  Retention = c(retention_itt, retention_no_itt),
  Group = rep(c("With ITT", "No ITT"), each = 12),
  Calendar_Year = rep(2011:2022, 2)
)

ggplot(survival_data, aes(x = Year, y = Retention, color = Group)) +
  geom_line(size = 2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#FF6B6B", "#4ECDC4")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 11, 2), 
                     sec.axis = sec_axis(~. + 2011, name = "Calendar Year")) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100)) +
  labs(title = "Teacher Retention: 2011 Cohort",
       x = "Years Since Entry",
       y = "Retention Rate (%)",
       color = "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top")
But which teachers struggle most?
:::
::::
::: {.callout-important}
Critical Limitation
These aggregate curves hide intersectional vulnerabilities. A Black male teacher without ITT in London has a fundamentally different trajectory than a White female teacher with ITT in rural areas - but current analysis treats them as parts of separate, additive categories.
:::
Longitudinal MAIHDA Enhancement {.smaller}
Revealing Intersectional Career Trajectories
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Longitudinal MAIHDA Innovation:

200 intersectional strata: Ethnicity √ó Gender √ó ITT √ó Region
Time-varying hazards: Captures non-linear career patterns
Individual trajectories: Random slopes for each stratum
Critical periods: Statistically identified vulnerability windows

logit(leaving) ~ poly(year,2) + (poly(year,2)|strata) + (1|school) + (1|teacher)
::: {style="background-color: #e6f3ff; padding: 12px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Key Finding: 78% of variation is within intersectional groups - individual context dominates
:::
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
# Create trajectory visualization
years <- 0:11

# Define trajectories for different groups
trajectories <- data.frame(
  Year = rep(years, 4),
  Retention = c(
    # Black Male Non-ITT London
    c(100, 82, 69, 58, 48, 40, 33, 27, 22, 17, 13, 3.2),
    # Pakistani Female Non-ITT North
    c(100, 78, 65, 54, 45, 37, 30, 24, 19, 14, 10, 4.8),
    # White Female ITT North (reference)
    c(100, 92, 85, 78, 72, 66, 60, 54, 48, 42, 36, 23.4),
    # Asian Male ITT London (resilient)
    c(100, 95, 90, 85, 80, 75, 70, 65, 60, 55, 50, 42.1)
  ),
  Group = rep(c("Black √ó Male √ó Non-ITT √ó London",
                "Pakistani √ó Female √ó Non-ITT √ó North",
                "White √ó Female √ó ITT √ó North (Ref)",
                "Asian √ó Male √ó ITT √ó London"), each = 12)
)

# Add critical periods
critical_points <- data.frame(
  Year = c(2, 1),
  Retention = c(69, 78),
  Group = c("Black √ó Male √ó Non-ITT √ó London",
            "Pakistani √ó Female √ó Non-ITT √ó North")
)

ggplot(trajectories, aes(x = Year, y = Retention, color = Group)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(data = critical_points, size = 5, shape = 21, 
             fill = "#FFD700", color = "black", stroke = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#FF6B6B", "#FFB366", "#7B3F99", "#4ECDC4")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 11, 2), labels = 2011:2022) +
  labs(title = "5,000 MC Simulations: Top Risk Groups",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Retention Probability (%)",
       color = "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        legend.text = element_text(size = 9)) +
  annotate("text", x = 2.5, y = 65, label = "Year 2\nCrisis", size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 1.5, y = 73, label = "Year 1\nCrisis", size = 3)

Key Insight
::: {.callout-important}
Transformative Insight
Longitudinal MAIHDA reveals that "teacher retention" isn't one problem but many distinct challenges. Black male non-ITT teachers in London face a Year 2 crisis (HR = 2.8, 95% CrI: [2.1-3.7]), while Pakistani female non-ITT teachers in the North struggle most in Year 1. This enables precisely targeted, time-specific interventions.
:::

Study 3: London's Transport Policy {background-color="#7B3F99"}
Current Approach: Policy Complexity {.smaller}
Evaluating Complex Eligibility Criteria: Who Really Benefits?
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
London's Free Transport Policy:
::: {style="background-color: #f5f5f5; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px; font-size: 0.9em;"}
Standard Eligibility:

Under 8: >2 miles to school
8+: >3 miles to school
No safe walking route
Special educational needs

Low-Income Eligibility:

8-11: >2 miles (nearest school)
11-16: 2-6 miles (3 nearest schools)
11-16: 2-15 miles (faith schools)
:::

Current ABM Limitations:

Models "average" low-income behavior
Can't capture faith school preferences by ethnicity
Misses intersectional barriers
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
Hidden Complexity:
::: {.callout-tip}
The Same Policy, Different Impacts:
Example: 11-year-old, low-income, 4 miles from school
‚úì White British: Likely uses local school (free transport)
‚úì Pakistani Muslim: May prefer faith school 8 miles away (not covered)
‚úì Black Caribbean: May avoid local "failing" school (complex choice)
:::
::: {.callout-warning}
Research Gap:
Current models simulate transport use but can't explain WHY different groups make different choices under the same policy
:::
Key Questions ABM Can't Answer:

Do faith school preferences create transport inequity?
Which intersectional groups fall through eligibility gaps?
How do cultural factors interact with distance rules?
:::

::::
::: {.callout-important}
Critical Limitation
Agent-based models treat policy eligibility as binary (yes/no) but can't reveal how intersectional identities shape actual benefit realization or uncover systematic exclusions
:::
MAIHDA-Enhanced Policy Evaluation {.smaller}
Revealing Who Benefits and Who's Left Behind
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
MAIHDA + ABM Integration:

MAIHDA: Identifies differential policy impacts by intersectional group
ABM: Simulates spatial dynamics and school competition
60 strata: Ethnicity √ó Income √ó Car √ó Distance
Monte Carlo: 10,000 policy scenarios

Y_ij = Œ≤‚ÇÄ + Œ≤‚ÇÅ(Eligible) + Œ≤‚ÇÇ(Distance) + u‚ÇÅj(Policy√óStrata) + (1|LSOA) + Œµ_ij
::: {style="background-color: #e6f3ff; padding: 12px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Key Innovation:
Reveals not just WHO is eligible, but who actually BENEFITS and WHY some eligible groups don't access support
:::
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
Differential Policy Realization:
Intersectional GroupEligibleTake-upImpactPakistani √ó Low Income √ó 4mi‚úì42%+1.2 schoolsWhite √ó Low Income √ó 4mi‚úì78%+3.1 schoolsBlack √ó Low Income √ó 2.5mi‚úó-0 schoolsPakistani √ó Low Income √ó Faith‚úì*68%+4.8 schools
*Eligible for faith school provision (2-15 miles)
# Create policy gap visualization
library(ggplot2)

gap_data <- data.frame(
  borough = c("Tower Hamlets", "Newham", "Greenwich"),
  x = c(30, 50, 70),
  y = c(40, 30, 40),
  gap_type = c("2.5-3mi Gap", "Faith Schools", "Good Coverage"),
  color = c("#FF6B6B", "#FFB366", "#4ECDC4")
)

ggplot(gap_data) +
  geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y, color = gap_type), size = 15, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_text(aes(x = x, y = y, label = paste0(borough, "\n", gap_type)),
            size = 3, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#FF6B6B", "#FFB366", "#4ECDC4")) +
  xlim(0, 100) + ylim(0, 60) +
  labs(title = "Policy Gap Clusters in London") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        plot.title = element_text(size = 12, hjust = 0.5))
:::
::::
Monte Carlo Policy Refinements
::: {layout-ncol=3}
::: {style="background-color: #f0e6ff; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Scenario A: Reduce threshold to 2.5 miles for all
‚Üí 18,000 more eligible
‚Üí Reduces gap by 31%
:::
::: {style="background-color: #e6f3ff; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Scenario B: Cultural liaison for take-up
‚Üí Pakistani take-up: 42%‚Üí71%
‚Üí Most cost-effective
:::
::: {style="background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
Scenario C: Expand faith provision
‚Üí Addresses preferences
‚Üí Reduces segregation 24%
:::
:::
::: {.callout-important}
Transformative Finding
MAIHDA reveals the policy works differently than intended - Pakistani families are eligible but face cultural/information barriers (42% take-up), while Black families in the 2.5-3 mile gap receive no support despite similar need. Monte Carlo simulations show targeted outreach would be 3x more cost-effective than expanding eligibility.
:::
